ALLEGATION:
Licensing agency should have closed a license on a foster home due to the
family’s permanency residence changing to Florida in March 2022. The
license was not closed until September 2022 even though the agency was
aware the family had moved.
INVESTIGATION:
I interviewed the Program Director and Licensing/Adoption Supervisors on
9/12/2022, to gather background information regarding the allegation. The program
director and supervisors reported that the agency became aware that the
foster/adoptive family on 2/9/2022 was in need to move to Florida due to the
foster/adoptive father’s job. The adoption supervisor said she and her coworkers
met with the family to discuss their need to move and received clarifying information.
She said the family had already communicated with the children’s Guardian ad litem
(GAL) who was in support of this move.
The Adoption Supervisor said she communicated with the permanency coordinator
at Oakland Court to make her aware of the situation/move. She said this person was
in support of communicating with Michigan Children’s Institute (MCI) to seek travel
permission and to complete the Interstate Compact on Placement for Children
(ICPC). The Adoption Supervisor said on the same day she contacted the DHHS
monitor prior to sending an email to MCI to make her aware of the foster/adoptive
family potential move.
The Adoption Supervisor said she emailed the MCI superintendent, another MCI
worker, DHHS Monitor, Oakland County Court Permanency Coordinator, and the
GAL on 02/15/2022 discussing the potential move of the foster/adoptive family move.
She said the MCI Superintendent responded and added another MCI worker on the
email.
The Program Director reported that her agency completed a relocation report for the
foster/adoptive family in Michigan in Davison where the family were renting on
01/27/2022. She said her agency was also aware during this time that the family
was looking to relocate to Florida but was keeping their home in Davison for visits for
the children they were going to adopt. She said no solid plans of closing their
license in Michigan had been made by the family. The Program Director said her
agency completed the family annual reevaluation on 05/09/2022 at the Davison
home.
I scheduled a TEAM meeting on 09/22/2022, with my Area Manager, the Program
Manager and Adoption Supervisor of the agency to discuss the allegation and to
identify when the foster/adoptive family informed the agency that they were
relocating to Florida and the interaction prior to the decision being made. The
agency provided a timeline, (names were removed) and it is as follows:
3

• 02/15/2022- the agency representatives completed a meeting with the
foster/adoptive family to discuss their need to move, receive clarifying
information. The family had already communicated with GAL who was in
support.
• 02/15/2022- Agency Adoption Supervisor communicated with permanency
coordinator at Oakland County Court. She was made aware of the situation and
was in support of communicating with MCI to seek travel permission/ and
complete interstate compact placement of Children (ICPC).
• 02/15/2022- Adoption Supervisor called DHHS monitor prior to sending email to
MCI to make their office aware of the relocation and receive directions of
concerns the agency had.
• 02/15/2022- Adoption Supervisor emailed MCI superintendent and another MCI
worker, DHHS monitor, Oakland County Court Permanency Coordinator, and the
Children’s GAL to discuss procedures for the relocation.
• 02/15/2022- MCI Superintendent responds and adds a second MCI worker to
the email.
• 02/15/2022- MCI provides permission for the family to travel (copy of email was
provided).
• 02/28/2022-Face to Face home visit was held between foster parents, children,
and the agency worker at their MI home.
• 03/02/2022-ICPC packet was emailed to the DHHS monitor.
• 03/03/2022-Face to Face home visit was held between foster parents, children,
and OFS worker at their MI home.
• 03/07/2022-03/09/2022-Email's between DHHS monitor and OFS worker.
(Emails were attached and reviewed about the ICPC by this Consultant.)
• 03/10/2022- Meeting occurred with local DHHS regarding ICPC. Meeting
included supervisor, section manager, OFS director, agency FC/AD supervisor.
• 4/28/2022-Face to Face home visit was held between foster parents, children,
and OFS worker at their MI home.
• 05/2/2022, the OFS worker completed her last in-person home visit with foster
family and the children at their MI residence. Agency foster care worker was
present and did her visit for their MI foster home license renewal. Foster Mother
had previously told the agency adoption supervisor and foster care worker that
she wanted to keep the MI foster home license open.
• On 5/25/2022 OFS & MDHHS received an email from MI ICPC informing the
agency that the foster parent’s FL home study was approved. That same day the
4

agency had a phone conference with the foster parent to discuss the home study
and the steps needed to complete the adoption process. The foster mother
informed the OFS adoption supervisor again verbally that she still wanted to
keep her MI license open.
• On 6/1/2022 the OFS worker received a text (which was verified by this
Consultant) where the foster mother told the adoption supervisor, she and the
foster father had 60 days to switch their driver's licenses to FL; the adoption
supervisor called the foster mother in response to all of her questions because
her requested information was too much to text.
• On 6/8/2022, OFS FC/AD supervisor and OFS Licensing staff notified the foster
mother that the FL home study was approved. The OFS staff discuss the closure
of the family Michigan license, but the foster mother didn't want to close the
license yet. (A text was provided with this information where this Consultant
reviewed the document.)
• On 06/13/2022 the ICPC adoption packet was submitted to the DHHS monitor.
• On 06/15/2022 a Family Team Meeting (FTM) was held with the FP's, OFS
FC/AD worker, OFS supervisor and MDHHS. The foster parents expressed in
the meeting that they wanted to keep their Michigan license open.
• On 8/31/2022 the foster parents confirmed that they wanted their MI foster care
license closed. (This information was in a text message).
• OFS sent a letter confirming the closure of the foster home on 09/01/2022. (This
information was verified by this Consultant).
• On 09/02/2022 MDHHS Wayne inquired to verify if OFS wanted the case close.
• The foster home of the foster parent was officially closed on 09/07/2022.
I observed several documents that included emails back and forth between the foster
family and OFS staff, MCI email of state travel, Bridges providers change request,
request from the foster parents requesting their license be close dated 8/31/2022,
review of the foster family reevaluation report and License from the State of Florida
for the foster parent. Florida also had to complete a license home study for the family
before prominent resident could take place.
There was no documentation to support that the foster family did not have a
prominent resident in Michigan. The family was given permission to travel back and
forth between Florida and Michigan per MCI travel request per the foster father job.
However, prominent residence remains in Michigan. All parties associated with this
case was aware of the circumstances surrounding the family movement and the
process it took for the relocation to Florida and the closure of the Michigan license.
5

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12403 Policy and procedures.
(2) The policies and procedures shall cover at least all of
the following areas:
(f) Unusual incidents.
ANALYSIS:
Based on interviews from the agency, the timeline,
documentation of emails, the agency acted appropriately with
the closure of the foster home license. The family had two
license open at the same time, one in Michigan and one in
Florida. The agency was aware that the foster home study was
completed. However, Oakland Family Services was not aware
that a license was issued in Florida until the family requested
closure of their Michigan License on 08/31/2022 and the license
was close on 09/07/2022 when the agency became aware that
the family had an open license in Florida. The agency
continued to wait on the ICPC for the adoption of the children.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended that Oakland Family Services License remains unchanged.
